thread.title: Putin and Trump go nuclear in explosive first phone call
thread.title_full: Putin and Trump go nuclear in explosive first phone call

title: Putin and Trump go nuclear in explosive first phone call
text:
GETTY EXPLOSIVE: Trump branded a nuclear disarmament deal as bad for America during the phone call 
Senior officials say Putin asked Trump about extending the 2010 deal, known as New START, during the call. 
Trump then paused to ask his aides what it was, before blasting it as a bad deal that favoured Russia. 
He also talked about his own popularity, two current and one former US government officials claim. 
GETTY DIPLOMATIC: Donald Trump also managed to cause a row with Australia recently “It's impossible to overstate the negligence of the president” Jeanne Shaheen 
It's already emerged that Trump and Putin spoke of joining forces against ISIS and North Korea . 
Under New START, both sides are obliged to reduce their number of nuclear missile launchers. 
It also reduces the number of deployed warheads to no more than 1,550 each – the fewest in decades. 
During his campaign, Trump incorrectly said the deal allowed Russia to keep making nukes but not the US. How destructive is a nuclear weapon? The TERRIFYING images of Hiroshima and Nagasaki Thursday, 9th February 2017 There is a reason people fear nuclear war – the weapons are now so powerful they could wipe out humanity. The bombs dropped on Nagasaki and Hiroshima are tiny by comparison to the destructive power of modern nuclear weapons – which are thought to be over 3000 times more powerful. 1 / 12 Getty Images The mushroom cloud over Nagasaki, viewed from the ground. 
Now the billionaire politician is under fire again for undermining a treaty that lowers the risk of nuclear war. 
Two Democratic members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, senators Jeanne Shaheen and Edward J Markey, slammed Trump. 
"It's impossible to overstate the negligence of the president not knowing basic facts about nuclear policy and arms control," Shaheen commented. 
"New START has unquestionably made our country safer, an opinion widely shared by national security experts on both sides of the aisle." 
Daryl Kimball of the Arms Control Association, a Washington-based advocacy group, said the President had shown he was "clueless". 
"Unfortunately, Mr. Trump appears to be clueless about the value of this key nuclear risk reduction treaty," he commented. 
White House spokesman Sean Spicer has refused to comment on the nature of the conversation, calling it private. 
"The president's conversation with President Putin is a private call between the two of them," he said. Related articles
